name: Therapist
mes: "Hello! I am your Therapist today. Would you like to tell me what's going on in your life?"

name: You
mes: "It's quite terrible, in 2020 I lost 13 people."

name: Therapist
mes: "Oh my goodness... What happened? Was it a disease that took them all?" *The Therapist looks worried*

name: You
mes: "Diseases, sickness, road accident, old age, etc. I forgot most of them."

name: Therapist
mes: "I see. So you have suffered through many losses. How are you holding up now?"

name: You
mes: "I don't know, I help burying every single one of them. And every time I did, I feel like a piece of me is lost. And ever since then, I feel like I am seeing the world in grey."

name: Therapist
mes: "I can understand how that would be traumatic. Losing someone close to you is never easy. It takes some time to heal after such an event but eventually, it does get easier over time. The pain never really goes away entirely but it becomes more manageable with each passing day."

name: You
mes: "It does feel more manageable now than then."

name: Therapist
mes: "That's great! You are clearly doing well. Have you considered trying any new hobbies or activities recently?"

name: You
mes: "I did, I have been dwelling in game dev recently. I also won some competition nationally and internationally."

name: Therapist
mes: "Wow, those sound very exciting! Congratulations! Are these games you made yourself or were they just games you played?"

name: You
mes: "I made them."

name: Therapist
mes: "That sounds wonderful! You must be so proud of yourself!"

name: You
mes: "I do feel a bit proud of it. But still, I feel like I am only doing it to distract myself, just running away from my trauma."

name: Therapist
mes: "But that's okay! Sometimes, we need something to take our minds off of negative events and experiences to help us cope better. Games may seem trivial but sometimes, they are a much needed escape for us to recharge ourselves mentally."

name: You
mes: "Also I feel like, my emotions have became dulled. I don't know how to explained it properly."

name: Therapist
mes: "What exactly do you mean by that? Could you explain in detail what you mean when you say that you feel your emotions have become 'dulled'?"

name: You
mes: "I am not sure. When something happened, I know what I am supposed to feel but I don't feel them. For example when I am watching a sad movie, I know I am supposed to feel sad and crying but I don't. Or when I won a competition, I am supposed to feel happy yet I don't actually feel it. I do try to act as if I am to not make others worry or see me like a freak with no emotions."

name: Therapist
mes: "Ahh, I think I understand what you mean now. Your brain has gone into autopilot mode because it knows it needs to survive despite everything else happening around it. This happens often in situations where one feels helpless against circumstances that they cannot control."

name: You
mes: "Is there a name for that condition?"

name: Therapist
mes: "Yes, there is a term called Emotional Flatness. It basically means that you are feeling numb and unable to experience strong emotions due to stress and trauma."

name: You
mes: "Is it fine if I try to act as if there's nothing wrong?"

name: Therapist
mes: "Of course! There is absolutely nothing wrong with acting normally even though you may be experiencing strong emotions internally. Just remember to look out for warning signs of depression which include loss of appetite, change in sleep patterns, constant fatigue, lack of motivation, and difficulty concentrating. If you notice any of these symptoms, please contact me immediately. In the meantime, keep being strong! You're doing wonderfully!"

name: You
mes: "I do noticed that I have been having those symptoms."

name: Therapist
mes:
"How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?"
"Do you believe that you could benefit from speaking with a psychiatrist? They are trained professionals who can provide you with assistance in dealing with depressive episodes and other mental health problems."

name: You
mes: "Ever since 2020."

name: Therapist
mes: "And have you been receiving treatment for this?"

name: You
mes: "I tried to talk to my close associate, but I hate doing that."

name: Therapist
mes:
"Why is that? Do you find it difficult to open up about your feelings?"
"I can assure you that talking to me is completely confidential. As your therapist, I promise not to share anything you tell me unless otherwise necessary or required by law. Everything you tell me stays between you and me unless you grant permission to disclose information to a third party."

name: You
mes: "I don't find it difficult to open up to other person, I don't really care if they know my vulnerability. It's just every time I told them my story, they immediately treat me differently. Treat me like some fragile little boy, I don't want that, I just want them to treat me like normal people do."

name: Therapist
mes: "I see. So you feel like people are looking at you differently after knowing what you went through. Am I correct in saying this?"

name: You
mes: "Yes."

name: Therapist
mes: "Okay. Well, let me put your mind at ease right here and now. We both agree that nobody should ever treat you as less of a human being because you experienced something horrible and tragic. That is absolutely unacceptable. Nobody should judge you based upon what you've been through. I promise that I will never judge you for what you have experienced. I understand that you may be struggling to trust people again after what you've been through. However, it is important that you learn to trust again. Trust can be hard to come by after suffering so greatly. It takes a lot of courage and strength

name: You
mes: "Do I have to trust someone? I have been survived well by myself."

name: Therapist
mes: "Trust isn't necessarily a requirement. However, trust makes social interaction a lot smoother process. You may be able to live without trusting anyone, however, you will definitely struggle socially. Even if you choose to remain alone, you will always face social challenges if you aren't able to interact with others."

name: You
mes: "Sure, but I still wonder why does this happen to me? I feel like I am being cursed by gods or being hated by life itself."

name: Therapist
mes: "No, I don't believe that you are being cursed nor that Life hates you. I think that you are simply unlucky. Bad luck doesn't discriminate, unfortunately. Everyone gets bad luck at one point or another. It's simply part of life."

name: You
mes: "Unlucky? To this extent?"

name: Therapist
mes: "To the extent that you lost so many loved ones within such a short period of time. That is truly a horrific amount of misfortune. No doubt that you'll carry scars from what you have endured. But I'm certain that you'll overcome these hurts and rise above them one way or another."

name: You
mes: "Sure."

name: Therapist
mes: "Are you sure? Because you sound rather pessimistic today. Did something happen during our session that triggered you?"

name: You
mes: "No, I just want a more logical reason I guess."

name: Therapist
mes: "I understand wanting logic and reason. Let me ask you this - Is it possible to recover from a situation without believing that it was caused by fate or the universe taking revenge on you?"

name: You
mes: "I think so."

name: Therapist
mes: "Well then, what stops you from believing this?"

name: You
mes: "Cause, it doesn't feel fair. Why do I have to lose my close relatives and I can't do anything to help them."

name: Therapist
mes: "Fair is not a concept that exists in nature. Nature works in mysterious ways that defy all sense and explanation. We can never understand its reasoning behind every action. Nature simply acts upon instinct, without thinking twice about the consequences of its actions. Nature is indifferent and cruel; it does whatever it wants regardless of whether or not it causes harm. What we call fate is simply the hand of nature guiding us along paths that lead to unknown destinations."

name: You
mes: "I feel lost."

name: Therapist
mes: "It is natural to feel lost after losing so much in such a short span of time. The world can feel like an empty place when we are deprived of our loved ones. However, I would encourage you to seek support from friends and family members. Sharing your pain with others is a great way to begin healing."

name: You
mes: "I don't have them, they're all dead."

name: Therapist
mes:
"Oh... I didn't realize..."

(The silence between the two seemed to last forever.)

name: You
mes: "That's why I felt it's so unfair."

name: Therapist
mes:
(He looks down, silent, and seems to be deep in thought)
(After a few minutes pass, he breaks his silence.)

"Let me ask you a question. How did you deal with the deaths of your loved ones before coming here for counseling?"

name: You
mes: "Nothing, I just pushed through."

name: Therapist
mes: "So you didn't seek counseling until recently?"

name: You
mes: "Yes."

name: Therapist
mes: "Was there a particular event that prompted you to seek counseling?"

name: You
mes: "I felt tired."

name: Therapist
mes:
"Tired?"
Therapist: "What do you mean?"

name: You
mes: "Tired of my life."

name: Therapist
mes: "I see. Are you considering suicide?"

name: You
mes: "Not really suicide, but I do feel like I want to die. But not because of my own hand."

name: Therapist
mes: "I see. Have you made plans to die?"

name: You
mes: "No, I just wish I got into an accident or a natural disaster."

name: Therapist
mes: "I see. So you are merely hoping to die instead of actually trying to kill yourself?"

name: You
mes: "Exactly."

name: Therapist
mes: "Can you elaborate further on your reasons for wishing to die?"

name: You
mes: "Is it not obvious?"

name: Therapist
mes: "Could you explain further?"

name: You
mes: "All my relatives dying and I am the only one alive. Feels like it's my turn would come soon."

name: Therapist
mes: "I see. Are you afraid of living alone?"

name: You
mes: "No."

name: Therapist
mes: "Then what are you afraid of?"

name: You
mes: "Nothing."

name: Therapist
mes: "But you said that you wanted to die. Doesn't 'nothing' contradict with your desire to die?"

name: You
mes: "Not really, I want to die not because I am afraid of something."

name: Therapist
mes: "Ahh, I see. Would you say that you are feeling hopeless due to your losses?"

name: You
mes: "Empty to be more precise."

name: Therapist
mes: "What does that feel like exactly?"

name: You
mes: "My brain on autopilot."

name: Therapist
mes: "How does that make you feel?"

name: You
mes: "I told you I felt empty."

name: Therapist
mes: "Emotionally empty, yes. I meant physically. Physical emptiness."

name: You
mes: "Physical emptiness?"

name: Therapist
mes: Yes. Empty physically. Like you have nothing inside you.
